contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Provinces of Japan-Hitachi.svg|thumb|300px|right|Map of Japanese provinces (1868) with Hitachi Province highlighted.]] {{nihongo|'''Hitachi Province'''|常陸国|Hitachi no Kuni}} was an [[old provinces of Japan|old province]] of [[Japan]] in the area of [[Ibaraki Prefecture]].<ref>[[Louis-Frédéric|Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric]]. (2005). "''Hitachi fudoki''" in {{Google books|p2QnPijAEmEC|''Japan Encyclopedia'', p. 336|page=336}}.</ref> It was sometimes called {{nihongo|'''Jōshū'''|常州}}. Hitachi Province bordered on [[Iwashiro Province|Iwashiro]], [[Iwaki Province|Iwaki]], [[Shimōsa Province|Shimōsa]], and [[Shimotsuke Province|Shimotsuke]] Provinces. The ancient provincial capital and temple were located near modern [[Ishioka, Ibaraki|Ishioka]] and have been excavated, while the chief shrine was further east at [[Kashima, Ibaraki|Kashima]]. In the [[Sengoku Period]] the area was divided among several daimyo, but the chief castle town was usually the modern city of [[Mito, Ibaraki|Mito]]. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * [[Louis-Frédéric|Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric]] and Käthe Roth. (2005).
